document.docAuthor: Annunziata, Bruno B. & Cavalcanti, Thaynã & Santos, George Garcia & Pinheiro, Ulisses
document.docTitle: Two new Clathria (Axosuberites) Topsent, 1893 (Demospongiae: Poecilosclerida) from Northeastern Brazil

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Two new Clathria (Axosuberites) Topsent, 1893 (Demospongiae: Poecilosclerida) from Northeastern Brazil

emphasis.docTitle:
Two new
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) Topsent, 1893
(Demospongiae: Poecilosclerida ) from Northeastern Brazil

subSection.paragraph:
BRUNO B. ANNUNZIATA 1,2,4 , THAYNÃ CAVALCANTI 1 , GEORGE GARCIA SANTOS 3 & ULISSES PINHEIRO 1
1
Universidade Federal de Pernambuco , Programa de Pós-Graduação em Biologia Animal (PPGBA), Av. Nelson Chaves, s/n Cidade Universitária, 50373-970, Recife, PE, Brazil .

paragraph.emphasis: Universidade Estadual do Piauí , Campus Alexandre Alves de Oliveira, Av. Nossa Sra. Fátima, s/n, 64202-220, Parnaíba, PI, Brazil
Universidade Federal do Cariri, Instituto de Formação de Educadores, Rua Olegário Emídio de Araújo, s/n, 63260-000, Brejo Santo, CE, Brazil .

subSection.paragraph:
The genus
Clathria Schmidt, 1862
is the richest genus of the family Microcionidae , but only 20 species have been recorded from Brazil until now.
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) Topsent, 1893
is characterized by having digitate, whip-like, arborescent and flabellate growth forms, lacking echinating spicules, well differentiated axial and extra-axial skeleton, styles and/or subtylostyles as principal spicules, and microscleres palmate isochelae and toxas. The subgenus contains 19 valid species, with worldwide distribution predominantly in shallow waters. Six species occur in the Atlantic Ocean and two of them are recorded from the Western Atlantic in South America:
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) riosae Van Soest, 2017
, and
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) marplatensis ( Cuartas, 1992 )
. Specimens analyzed in this study were collected in 2015 at Mamanguape estuary, Paraíba State , and in 2017 at Tutóia beach, Maranhão State . Here we described two new species of
Clathria ( Axosuberites )
for the first time in Brazilian waters:
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) aurantia
n. sp.
and
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi
n. sp.
Key words: marine sponges, Microcionidae , Western Atlantic, taxonomy

Microcionidae is characterized by having three skeletal regions defined by the presence of different forms of structural styles: choanosomal (axial) skeleton (spicules enclosed within spongin fibres and spined monactinal spicules typically echinating fibres), subectosomal (extra-axial or extra-fibre) skeleton and ectosomal skeleton; one or more skeletal regions may be lost or modified ( Hooper 2002 ). Two genera and two subgenera of this family are characterized by lacking the echinating spicules in their skeleton composition (
Artemisina Vosmaer, 1885
,
Ophlitaspongia Bowerbank, 1866
,
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) Topsent, 1893
and
Clathria ( Isociella ) Hallman, 1920
), and in other genera, such as
Antho Gray, 1867
, echinating spicules may be present (
Antho ( Acarnia ) Gray, 1867
) or absent (
Antho ( Antho ) Gray, 1867
and
Antho ( Isopenectya ) Hallmann, 1920
).

The genus
Clathria Schmidt, 1862
is the richest genus within Microcionidae and consists of nine subgenera and 388 valid species, six of these remain unassigned to a subgenus (
Van Soest et al ., 2019
). In Brazil , eighteen species and four subgenera of
Clathria
are recorded ( Muricy, 2019 ):
Clathria ( Clathria ) calypso Boury-Esnault, 1973
; C .
( C .) nicoleae Barros, Santos & Pinheiro, 2013
,
C . ( Microciona ) achelata Sandes & Pinheiro, 2016
, C .
( M .) calla (De Laubenfels, 1934)
, C .
( M .) campecheae Hooper, 1996
, C .
( M .) crassitoxa Santos & Pinheiro, 2014
, C . ( M .) danielae Cavalcanti, Santos & Pinheiro, 2018, C .
( M .) echinata ( Alcolado, 1984 )
, C . ( M .) larae Cavalcanti, Santos & Pinheiro, 2018, C . ( M .) moraesi Cavalcanti, Santos & Pinheiro, 2018, C . ( M .) nisiae Cavalcanti, Santos & Pinheiro, 2018, C .
( M .) trairae Santos & Pinheiro, 2014
;
C . ( Thalysias ) basiarenacea ( Boury-Esnault, 1973 )
; C .
( T .) curacaoensis Arndt, 1927
; C .
( T .) minuta ( Van Soest, 1984 )
, C .
( T .) repens Galindo, Hooper and Pinheiro, 2014
; C .
( T .) venosa ( Alcolado, 1984 )
, and
C . ( Wilsonella ) nigra ( Boury-Esnault, 1973 )
. All occur in the Northeastern region and only the species C .
( M .) campecheae
and C .
( T .) minuta
co-occur in the Southeastern region. Prior to this study no
Clathria ( Axosuberites )
species were known from Brazil .

Clathria ( Axosuberites )
is recognized by having skeleton compressed and well differentiated from plumose(- reticulate) extra-axial skeleton; echinating spicules absent; ectosomal skeleton with special category of (smaller) auxiliary style forming surface brushes ( Hooper 2002 ). Nineteen described species comprise the subgenus, two of which are known for South America coast:
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) riosae Van Soest, 2017
(from Suriname ) and
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) marplatensis ( Cuartas, 1992 )
(from Mar del Plata, Argentina ). However, neither of these occur in Brazil . Herein, we provide a description of two new species of
Clathria ( Axosuberites )
from northeastern Brazil , being the first records for the subgenus from the Brazilian coast.

Specimens were collected by free diving at Paraíba State , municipality of Rio Tinto (Mamanguape estuary) ( 06°46’43.46’’S 34°55’55.61’’W ) in 2015, and dragged by fishing net in Tutóia beach ( 02º45’13.000”S , 42º17’16.977”W ), Tutóia Municipality, Maranhão State in 2017 ( Figure 1 ). All specimens were preserved in 80% ethanol and are deposited in the Porifera Collection at Universidade Federal de Pernambuco (UFPEPOR). Dissociated spicules and skeletal sections were prepared following
Hajdu et al . (2011)
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Map showing the type localities of the species described in this study (created in QGIS software) (MA—Maranhão State; PB—Paraíba State). Black dot:
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) aurantia
sp. nov.
; Black triangle:
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi
sp. nov.

subSection.paragraph:
Measurements are given in micrometers (μm), arranged as minimum– mean –maximum. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) preparations and eletromicrographs were undertaken at CETENE ( Centro de Tecnologias Estratégicas do Nordeste) and Fundação Oswaldo Cruz (Fiocruz)— Pernambuco / Centro de Pesquisas Aggeu Magalhães (CPqAM) and at Centro de Pesquisa Gonçalo Moniz, Fundação Oswaldo Cruz (FIOCRUZ-BA). Images of specimens, sections (Leica DM 500 microscope) and SEM (Jeol JSM-5600LV) preparations were obtained digitally. Taxonomic classification followed the World Porifera Database (
Van Soest et al . 2019
) available for
Clathria ( Axosuberites )
species.

subSubSection.paragraph: Synonymy (see Hooper 2002 ).

Diagnosis. Digitate, whip-like, arborescent and flabellate growth forms; with well differentiated axial and extraaxial skeletal architecture, reminiscent of Raspailiidae ; axial skeleton markedly compressed, reticulate; extra-axial skeleton radial, plumose or plumo-reticulate composed of large subectosomal auxiliary styles-subtylostyles; specialised ectosomal skeleton present composed of smaller auxiliary spicules; echinating megascleres absent although principal spicules may protrude through fibres at acute angles; microscleres absent or may include palmate isochelae and toxas ( Hooper 2002 ).

Type locality:
Brazil , Maranhão State
, Tutóia Municipality, Tutóia beach, Brazil .

materialsCitation.collectorName: B. Annunziata & A. Silva & L. H. O. Souza

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype :
UFPEPOR 2351, Tutóia beach ( 02º45’13.000” S , 42º17’16.977” W ), Tutóia Municipality , Maranhão State , Brazil , coll. B. Annunziata , R . A. Silva , L. H. O. Souza ,
24 July 2017
.

subSubSection.paragraph: External morphology. Bush sponge emerging at encrusting base, with flattened branches measuring 6.25 x 0.53 cm (7.0– 5.5 cm x 0.8– 0.3 cm ) ( Fig. 2A ). Oscula inconspicuous, hispid surface and soft consistency. Orange color in life, and dark gray in 80% ethanol ( Fig. 2B ).

Skeleton ( Fig. 2C ). Choanosomal skeleton with differentiated axial and extra-axial regions: axial skeleton compressed and ascending, extra-axial skeleton plumo-reticulate or confused. Ectosomal skeleton produced by spicules from the extra-axial skeleton forming discrete bouquets of subtylostyles. Styles placed at the axial skeleton and subtylostyles protruding into extra-axial skeleton at acute angles. Palmate isochelae dispersed within choanosome.

Spicules. Megascleres: Styles (167– 396.4 –522 /
3– 7 – 10
µm): smooth, slender straight to slightly curved, with rounded base ( Fig. 3A,C ); Subtylostyles (171– 354.9 –488 / 3– 5.5 – 10 µm ): straight with microspined base, and pointed or mucronate points ( Fig. 3B,D ); Microscleres: palmate isochelae (10– 15.1 – 19 µm ): normal shaft to slightly curved “V”-shaped shaft and short alae ( Fig. 3E ).

Distribution and ecology. The specimen was found in Tutóia Channel, about 9.5 km from the shore and was collected dragged by fishing nets, in Tutóia beach, Tutóia municipality, Maranhão State , Brazil .
Etymology. From Latin “ aurantius ” referring to its vivid orange color in life.

Remarks.
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) aurantia
n . sp .
as well as C.
( A .) papillata Van Soest, Beglinger & De Voogd, 2013
, and C.
( A .) riosae Van Soest, 2017
differ from other C. ( Axosuberites ) species by the absence of toxas. However, the new species has smooth styles and one category of subtylostyles versus microspined styles in C.
( A .) papillata
and two size categories of subtylostyles in C.
( A .) riosae
(see Table 1 ). The main difference between
C . ( Axosuberites ) aurantia
n . sp .
and C.
( A .) pachyaxia ( Lévi, 1960 )
and C.
( A .) georgiaensis Hooper, 1996
is the presence of toxas. In addition, there are some differences in the categories of their spicule arrangements and geographic distributions making specificity unlikely (see Table 1 ). Species of Axosuberites that have more than two categories of megascleres are:
C. ( A. ) benguelaensis Samaai & Gibbons, 2005
,
Clathria
( A .) canaliculata ( Whitelegge, 1906 )
,
C. ( A. ) cylindrica ( Ridley & Dendy, 1886 )
, C.
( A .) flabellata (Topsent, 1916)
, C.
( A .) nidificata ( Kirkpatrick, 1907 )
, C .
( A .) patula ( Hooper, 1996 )
, and C .
( A .) thetidis ( Hallmann, 1920 )
. Species with much larger isochelae and stout styles are C .
( A .) fromontae Hooper, 1996
, C .
( A .) macrotoxa ( Bergquist & Fromont, 1988 )
, C.
( A .) marplatensis ( Cuartas, 1992 )
and C .
( A .) multitoxaformis ( Bergquist & Fromont, 1988 )
. Furthermore, two species show larger megascleres when compared to
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) aurantia
n . sp .
:
Clathria
( A .) ramea ( Koltun, 1964 )
and C.
( A .) rosita Goodwin, Brewin & Brickle, 2012
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) aurantia
n. sp.
(UFPEPOR 2351). (A) specimen in situ ; (B) Preserved specimen; (C) Architecture of skeleton. Scale bars: A = 3 cm; B = 3 cm; C = 300 μm.

FIGURE 3.
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) aurantia
n. sp.
(UFPEPOR 2351). A, Styles; B, Subtylostyles; C. Basal end of style; D. Basal end of microspined subtylostyle; E, palmate isochelae. Scale bars: A, B = 50 μm; C, D = 10 μm; E = 2 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality:
Brazil , Paraíba State
,
Rio Tinto Municipality , Caracabu River , Mamanguape Estuary, Brazil
.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype :
UFPEPOR 1975, Caracabu River , Mamanguape Estuary ( 06°46’43.46’’S 34°55’55.61’’W ), Rio Tinto Municipality , Paraíba State , Brazil , intertidal (depth
0.5 m
), coll. T . Cavalcanti ,
11 November 2015
.

subSubSection.paragraph: External morphology ( Fig. 4A ). Arborescent sponge with filiform ramifications, cylindrical branches with 2 x 0.4 cm (length x width). Hispid surface, firm and compressible consistency. Oscula not observed. Red color when alive, and dark brown in 80% ethanol.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Measurements of
Clathria ( Axosuberites )
species spicular set.

tr.td: Port Jackson Bay, Australia / Manning-Hawkesbury / 40-70 m
South Georgia, Antartic Penin- sula / 92 m
South Georgia, Antartic Penin- sula / 18-236 m
South Georgia, Antartic Penin- sula / 90-540 m

tr.th:
Clathria
( A .) papillata Van Soest, Beglinger & De Voogd, 2013
5

Clathria
( A .) rosita Goodwin, Brewin & Brickle, 2012
2
tr.td: South Georgia, Antartic Penin- sula / 11.5 m

paragraph.tableNote:
References: (1) Samai & Gibbons (2005); (2)
Goodwin et al . (2012)
; (3) Lévi (1960) ; (4)
Van Soest et al . (2013)
; (5) Van Soest (2017) ; (6) Hooper (1996) ; (7) Bergquist & Fromont (1988) .

subSubSection.paragraph: Skeleton ( Fig. 4B ). Ectosome with brushes of small subtylostyles (styles II) overlapping the subectosomal spicules. Choanosomal skeleton composed of plumo-reticulate and compressed, extra-axial plumose tracts cored by (subtylo-)styles I. Plumose gaps near the surface. Subectosomal region composed by ascending plumose bundles of auxiliary subtylostyles arising from the peripheral choanosomal skeleton. Microscleres appear to be randomly distributed.

Spicules. Megascleres: (Subtylo-)styles I (270– 371.2 –447 / 6– 7.5 – 11 µm ): smooth to microspined, slightly curved, and rounded tyles, smooth to granular microspined tyles in some spicules ( Fig. 5A, D ); (Subtylo-)styles II (143– 179.8 –236 / 6– 8.1 – 10 µm ): smooth, slightly curved, and smooth, some styles II have microspined tyles ( Fig. 5B, F ); Subtylostyles (193– 307.6 –377 / 2– 2.5 – 3 µm ): smooth, slender, straight, microspined tyles ( Fig. 5C, E ); Microscleres: Palmate isochelae (12– 14.6 – 17 µm ): slightly curved axis and short alae ( Fig. 5G ); Toxas (24– 57.3 –96 / 1– 2.0 – 4 µm ): wing shaped, smooth, and slender ( Fig. 5H ).

Distribution and ecology. Known only from the type locality: Caracabu River/Estuary (Rio Tinto Municipality, Paraíba State , Brazil ), intertidal. Found in a mangrove area on roots of
Rhizophora
sp.
Etymology. The specific name is in honor to Stephen M. Hillenburg, marine biologist and creator of the cartoon character ‘SpongeBob SquarePants’.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi
n. sp.
(UFPEPOR 1975). A, preserved specimen; B, cross section showing the ectosome and choanosome. Scale bars: A = 2.5 cm; B = 500 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks.
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi
n. sp.
is characterized by a spicule arrangement with (subtylo-)styles I and II, auxiliary subtylostyles, toxa and palmate isochelae. The new species resembles to
Clathria
( A .) flabellata (Topsent, 1916)
and
Clathria
( A .) georgiaensis Hooper, 1996
(from the Antarctic Peninsula) by having two categories of styles and/or subtylostyles, toxas and palmate isochelae. However,
Clathria ( A .) hillenburgi
n. sp.
is distinguished from
Clathria
( A .) flabellata
and
Clathria
( A .) georgiaensis
due having shorter styles and toxas (see Table 1 ). Differences in megascleres categories among the new species and
Clathria
( A .) benguelaensis Samaai & Gibbons, 2005
,
Clathria
( A .) nidificata ( Kirkpatrick, 1907 )
include the number of megascleres categories (two in the new species and four in the others).
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi
n. sp.
distinguished from
Clathria
( A .) marplatensis ( Cuartas, 1992 )
,
Clathria
( A .) pachyaxia ( Lévi, 1960 )
,
Clathria
( A .) papillata Van Soest, Beglinger & De Voogd, 2013
,
Clathria
( A .) ramea ( Koltun, 1964 )
, and
Clathria
( A .) rosita Goodwin, Brewin & Brickle, 2012
by having two categories of styles and one of subtylostyle versus two categories of styles in the others. The new species differs from C.
( A .) aurantia
n. sp.
, C.
( A .) riosae Van Soest, 2017
and C.
( A .) papillata Van Soest, Beglinger & De Voogd, 2013
by the absence of toxas.
Clathria
( A .) canaliculata
and
C. ( A. ) cylindrica
have two categories of palmate isochelae, while the new species has only one category. Similarly,
C. ( A. ) fromontae
,
C. ( A. ) macrotoxa
,
C. ( A. ) multitoxaformis
and
C. ( A. ) thetidis
have two size categories of toxas, while
C. ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi
n. sp.
has only one category. Finally, the new species is distinguished from
Clathria ( A. ) patula ( Hooper, 1996 )
by having three categories of styles.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi
n. sp.
(UFPEPOR 1975). A, choanosomal principal styles (I); B, choanosomal principal styles (II); C, subectosomal subtylostyles; D, styles I detail; E, subtylostyles detail; F, styles II detail; G, palmate isochelae; H, toxas. Scale bars: A, C = 100 μm; B, D–F, H = 50 μm; G = 20 μm.

subSection.paragraph:
In
Clathria
, two subgenera ( Axosuberites and Isociella ) lacking echinating acanthostyles. Two other genera of Microcionidae also lack echinating acanthostyles:
Artemisina
and
Ophlitaspongia
. In one genus (
Antho
) echinating spicules may be present (
Antho
( Acarnia )) or absent (
Antho ( Antho)
and
Antho
( Isopenectya )) ( Hooper 2002 ). The presence of echinating megascleres in Microcionidae can indicate the retention of an ancestral character ( Hooper 1991 ), but only through molecular analysis this condition can be confirmed.

The largest number of species placed in this genus may indicate that some species of other Microcionidae genera are misassigned as
Clathria
. The species
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) nidificata
and
Clathria ( Axosuberites ) flabellata
were originally described as
Ophlitaspongia
. These species were transferred to
Clathria ( Axosuberites )
due having different morphologies than seen in
Ophlitaspongia
, including an erect and fan-shaped form with ramifications in
C . ( Axosuberites ) flabellata
, and massive and globular form in
C . ( Axosuberites ) nidificata ( Hooper, 1996 )
.
Clathria ( Axosuberites )
and
Ophlitaspongia
share the presence of subtylostyles, toxas and palmate isochelae, and absence of echinating megascleres. However, species in
Ophlitaspongia
have encrusting growth form and isodictyal reticulate spongin fibre skeleton arising from a hymedesmioid basal fibre skeleton ( Hooper 2002 ). There are other encrusting
Clathria
(mainly
Clathria ( Microciona )
and
Clathria
( Thalysias )) with absence of acanthostyles and similar spicule complement that should be revised.

With the description of C .
( A .) aurantia
sp. nov.
and C .
( A .) hillenburgi
sp. nov .
, the Brazilian diversity of
Clathria
is now increased to twenty species and five subgenera of
Clathria
.

This study is part of B.B. Annunziata’s PhD thesis through the Graduate Program in Animal Biology (Programa de Pós-Graduação em Biologia Animal) of the Departamento de Zoologia, UFPE. Daniele Mariz and Adélia Alliz for technical support. B. B. Annunziata thanks Maura R . A. Mendes, Neidson Costa , Renan Araújo, Lorena H. Souza, Leticia Valle and Lara Sousa for logistic and technical support. Funding was provided by the FACEPE (Fundação de Amparo à Ciência e Tecnologia de Pernambuco ) to T .C., FUN- CAP (Edital nº 03/2018—BP3-0139-00379.01.00/18) and CNPq (Edital nº 28/2018—Universal 432900/2018-7) to G.G.S. Two anonymous reviewers provided constructive comments on the originally submitted manuscript. We further thank CNPq (National Counsel of Technological and Scientific Development, Edital PROTAX: 562320/2010-5 and Universal 454908/2014-8 to U.P.) and FACEPE (APQ-0839-2.04/08 to U.P.), for providing grants and/or fellowships.
